scenarioDescription:
The HD 98219 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 98219 is a star with 1.41 times the mass of the Sun, and 4.6 times its radius. It is located 370.85 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 4 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HD 98219 is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 98219 system


HD 98219 b

HD 98219 b was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2011-12, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 1.26 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 98219 b is 624.552 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 98219 b is 13.400 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 98219 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 98219, which contains 1 exoplanets and was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory.
name: HD 98219 - System With 1 Exoplanet
